issue.title: Use JUnit 5 for running all tests

repository.name: netty
repository.description: Netty project - an event-driven asynchronous network application framework

issue.body:
Motivation:
JUnit 5 is the new hotness. It's more expressive, extensible, and composable in many ways, and it's better able to run tests in parallel. But most importantly, it's able to directly run JUnit 4 tests.
This means we can update and start using JUnit 5 without touching any of our existing tests.
I'm also introducing a dependency on assertj-core, which is like hamcrest, but arguably has a nicer and more discoverable API.

Modification:
Add the JUnit 5 and assertj-core dependencies, without converting any tests at time time.

Result:
All our tests are now executed through the JUnit 5 Vintage Engine.
Also, the JUnit 5 test APIs are available, and any JUnit 5 tests that are added from now on will also be executed.

This PR introduces the JUnit 5 infrastructure (no existing tests are changed) that #10757 talks about.

body:
Is there any reason that JUnit 5 cannot be added to Netty 4.1?

Considering test artifacts are not exported as part of the build process, it doesn't seem like it should pose a compatibility issue.

The testsuite is exposed so we can consume it . That said I would not consider this API

> Am 30.10.2020 um 21:16 schrieb Bennett Lynch <notifications@github.com>:
> 
> ﻿
> Is there any reason that JUnit 5 cannot be added to Netty 4.1?
> 
> Considering test artifacts are not exported as part of the build process, it doesn't seem like it should pose a compatibility issue.
> 
> —

> Reply to this email directly, view it on GitHub, or unsubscribe.

issue.title: Use JUnit 5 for running all tests

repository.name: netty
repository.description: Netty project - an event-driven asynchronous network application framework

issue.body:
Motivation:
JUnit 5 is the new hotness. It's more expressive, extensible, and composable in many ways, and it's better able to run tests in parallel. But most importantly, it's able to directly run JUnit 4 tests.
This means we can update and start using JUnit 5 without touching any of our existing tests.
I'm also introducing a dependency on assertj-core, which is like hamcrest, but arguably has a nicer and more discoverable API.

Modification:
Add the JUnit 5 and assertj-core dependencies, without converting any tests at time time.

Result:
All our tests are now executed through the JUnit 5 Vintage Engine.
Also, the JUnit 5 test APIs are available, and any JUnit 5 tests that are added from now on will also be executed.

This PR introduces the JUnit 5 infrastructure (no existing tests are changed) that #10757 talks about.
This PR replaces #10758 by moving the JUnit migration to 4.1 instead of 5.x.

body: JUnit 5 is now enabled in both the `4.1` branch and the `master` branch.

issue.title: Migrate some tests to JUnit 5

repository.name: netty
repository.description: Netty project - an event-driven asynchronous network application framework

issue.body:
I had some free time so I thought I would start work towards completing #10757.

https://github.com/netty/netty/issues/10757#issuecomment-848445551
